title: Sheet 3C
publication_title: James Ensor: The Temptation of Saint Anthony
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body">Part of the upended hot-air balloon from sheet 3B enters this sheet from the left. A number of wranglers, tethered to the balloon by ropes, fly through the space, while an enormous octopus—part of the biological debris that fills the sky—floats by. Connections exist between this sheet and the adjacent ones, but various details suggest they were created separately. For example, although the clouds continue to the adjacent sheet, 3D, Ensor created these in the present sheet with broad cross-hatching, whereas in 3D he used fine, parallel lines. This contrast in handling implies the two sheets were not conceived as a unit. Similarly, only one of the octopus’s tentacles extends down into sheet 4C, rather superficially. Thus it appears to be a later addition, made to link otherwise independent compositions. SMC/KJN

The action in sheets 3A, 3B, 3C, 4A, 4B, and 4C is the source of the engraving Devils Thrashing Angels and Archangels (fig. 1). It also indirectly inspired other etchings, such as The Terrible Archer (fig. 2), Cataclysms (fig. 3), Wizards in a Squall (fig. 4), and The Elephant’s Joke (fig. 5). Although Devils Thrashing Angels and Archangels is not a direct reproduction of these sheets, the chaotic composition and frightful elements are similar to Saint Anthony’s torments. Many motifs appear in both the print and the drawing, for example, the hot-air balloon, train, sawfish, headless bodies, octopi, insects, elephant, and submarine.

In the drawing the chaos is somewhat contained by the use of schematic registers, but in the etching Ensor dispensed with the organizational structure and allowed the chaos to become overwhelming. Sources of inspiration for the chaos include The Fall of the Rebel Angels by Pieter Bruegel I (fig. 6); versions of the temptation after Pieter Bruegel (fig. 7), by Martin Schongauer (fig. 8), and by Jacques Callot (fig. 9); and battle scenes by the Japanese artists Utagawa Kuniyoshi and Utagawa Kunisada (fig. 10 and fig. 11). These artists provided ideas about overlapping, clashing compositions that Ensor assimilated into his own work. He interpreted these sources to offer viewers a distilled representation that condenses the energy, imagination, anxiety, and virulence of its predecessors. Thanks to this synthesis, the image possesses its own logic and magic that captivates even as it amuses and overwhelms viewers with its detail. ST

fig. 1 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). Devils Thrashing Angels and Archangels, 1888. Etching from a copper plate, in black with hand-coloring, on buff laid paper; image: 24.8 × 28.7 cm (9 3/4 × 11 5/16 in.); plate: 26.3 × 30.7 cm (10 3/8 × 12 1/8 in.); sheet: 33.3 × 50.8 cm (13 1/8 × 20 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Olivia Shaler Swan Fund Income, 1971.629.

fig. 2 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). The Terrible Archer, 1888. Etching from a zinc plate, in black, on cream wove paper; image/plate: 17.7 × 23.9 cm (7 × 9 3/8 in.); sheet: 28.3 × 39.5 cm (11 1/8 × 15 9/16 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Print and Drawing Club Fund, 1946.1042.

fig. 3 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). Cataclysms, 1888. Etching from a zinc plate, in black, on cream wove paper; image: 17.5 × 23.5 cm (6 7/8 × 9 1/4 in.); plate: 17.9 × 23.8 cm (7 1/16 × 9 3/8 in.); sheet: 34 × 47.2 cm (13 3/8 × 18 5/8 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Joseph Brooks Fair Fund, 1943.1020.

fig. 4 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). Wizards in a Squall, 1888. Etching from a zinc plate, in black, on cream wove paper; image/plate: 17.9 × 23.6 cm (7 1/16 × 9 5/16 in.); sheet: 28.6 × 39.9 cm (11 1/4 × 15 3/4 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Print and Drawing Club Collection, 1946.264.

fig. 5 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). The Elephant’s Joke, 1888. Etching on paper; 17.9 × 23.8 cm (7 1/16 × 9 3/8 in.). Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, Gift of A. Justin and Lynn M. Sterling, 2005.171.4. © Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco.

fig. 6 Pieter Bruegel I (Flemish, c. 1525–1569). The Fall of the Rebel Angels, 1562. Oil on panel; 117 × 162 cm (46 × 64 in.). Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium, Brussels, 584. © Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium, Brussels/photograph: J. Geleyns/Ro scan.

fig. 7 Pieter van der Heyden (Flemish, c. 1530–after 1572) after Pieter Bruegel I (Flemish, c. 1525–1569). The Temptation of Saint Anthony, 1556. Engraving on laid paper; 24.3 × 32.5 cm (9 9/16 × 12 13/16 in.). The Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute, 2001.13.3. Image © Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute, Williamstown, Massachusetts, USA (photograph by Michael Agee).

fig. 8 Martin Schongauer (German, c. 1450–1491). The Temptation of Saint Anthony, 1470–75. Engraving in black on cream laid paper; sheet: 32 × 23.5 cm (12 5/16 × 9 1/16 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Gift of Mrs. Potter Palmer, Jr., 1955.1227.

fig. 9 Jacques Callot (French, 1592–1635). The Temptation of Saint Anthony, 1635. Etching in black on ivory laid paper; image/sheet (trimmed to platemark): 35.6 × 46.6 cm (14 × 18 3/8 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Print and Drawing Special Account, 1938.1250.

fig. 10 Utagawa Kuniyoshi (Japanese, 1797–1861). Published by Kogaya Katsugorō (Japanese, c. 1843–1874). <emthe and="" battle="" dan-no-ura:="" em="" nagon="" no="" of="" sagami="" suke="" taira="">, c. 1844. Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper; vertical ōban triptych; 36.7 × 75.3 cm (14 7/16 × 29 5/8 in.). Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, William Sturgis Bigelow Collection, 11.27029-31. Photograph © 2014 Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.</emthe>

fig. 11 Utagawa Kunisada (Japanese, 1786–1864). Published by Kawaguchiya Uhei (Japanese, c. 1800–1852). The Killing of Ten (Jūban kiri): Soga Gorō Tokimune and Gosho no Gorōmaru Shigemune, c. 1820. Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper; vertical ōban; 39 × 25.5 cm (15 3/8 × 10 1/16 in.).Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, William Sturgis Bigelow Collection, 11.21579. Photograph © 2014 Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.
